title: Analysis of Functions with Eulers and Taylor Poly

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with five columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “g prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is 2. g prime of x is 20. Column 2. x is 2.1. g prime of x is 39. Column 3. x is 2.2. g prime of x is 56. Column 4. x is 2.3. g prime of x is 71. Column 5. x is 2.4. g prime of x is 84." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="true" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="center" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>39</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>56</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>71</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>84</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Let <math alttext="y equals g of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x, equals g prime of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="g of 2 equals 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> are given in the table above. The function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is three-times differentiable. (a) Use the local linear approximation of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to approximate <math alttext="g of 2.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with five columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “g prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is 2. g prime of x is 20. Column 2. x is 2.1. g prime of x is 39. Column 3. x is 2.2. g prime of x is 56. Column 4. x is 2.3. g prime of x is 71. Column 5. x is 2.4. g prime of x is 84." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="true" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="center" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>39</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>56</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>71</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>84</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Let <math alttext="y equals g of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x, equals g prime of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="g of 2 equals 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> are given in the table above. The function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is three-times differentiable. (a) Use the local linear approximation of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to approximate <math alttext="g of 2.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Find the average rate of change of <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> over the interval <math alttext="2 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 2.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(c) Let <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, 6 plus, open parenthesis, g of x, close parenthesis, squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="h prime of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(d) Use a midpoint Riemann sum with two subintervals of equal length and values from the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 2 to 2.4, of, g prime of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2.4</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(e) It is known that <math alttext="g triple prime of x is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="2 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 2.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the approximation from part (d) an overestimate or an underestimate for <math alttext="the integral from 2 to 2.4, of, g prime of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2.4</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(f) Use Euler’s method, starting at <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with two steps of equal size, to approximate <math alttext="g of 2.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(g) It is known that <math alttext="g double prime of 2 equals 200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g triple prime of 2 equals negative 200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>200</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write the third-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 2.1: Defining Average and Instantaneous Rates of Change at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
